Biochemistry. 1998; 37: 5394-5406Crossref PubMed Scopus (134) Google Scholar). Briefly, the substrate (or substrate analog) binding to the α-active site induces an ordering of the catalytically important loops αL2 and αL6 and a concerted rearrangement of both gating residues βTyr279 and βPhe280 (9Ruvinov S.B. Yang X.J. Parris K.D. Banik U. Ahmed S.A. Miles E.W. Sackett D.L. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 6357-6369Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (57) Google Scholar, 13Rhee S. Parris K.D. Ahmed S.A. Miles E.W. Davies D.R. Biochemistry. 1996; 35: 4211-4221Crossref PubMed Scopus (137) Google Scholar, 14Weyand M. Schlichting I. Biochemistry. 1999; 38: 16469-16480Crossref PubMed Scopus (76) Google Scholar), resulting in tunnel blockage and thus preventing untimely passage of indole. The ordering of a rigid but movable domain (βGly102–βGly189) is concomitant. We named it the “COMM domain” because it is central to the α ↔ β-active site communication. Rhee et al. (15Rhee S. Parris K.D. Hyde C.C. Ahmed S.A. Miles E.W. Davies D.R. Biochemistry. 1997; 36: 7664-7680Crossref PubMed Scopus (143) Google Scholar) introduced the domain βGly93–βGly189 as the “mobile region.” This COMM domain interacts with residues of α-subunit loops αL2 and αL6, β-subunit residues including βAsp305, which is involved in binding of the metal ion, and active site residues βGlu109 and βGln114. Changes on either active site disrupt the respective interactions with the COMM domain, which results in a rigid body movement of the COMM domain, thereby changing the interactions at the other active site and thus transmitting the signal.We decided to revisit the βA169L/βC170W mutant to see whether our model provides the structural basis for the changed kinetic properties of the mutant. Our previous study of the βA169L/βC170W mutant was hampered by the low resolution (3.2 Å) of the structure determined using x-rays from a rotating anode. Therefore, we redetermined the structure of the mutant complexed with the noncleavable IGP analogue 5-fluoro-indole propanol phosphate (F-IPP) to 2.25 Å resolution using synchrotron radiation. The comparison of the kinetic properties of the single mutant βC170F and the double mutant βA169L/βC170W, together with the comparison of the structures of the latter and the wild-type enzyme, suggests the reason for the impaired inter-subunit communication being the βA169L mutation, whereas the βC170W replacement seems to be responsible for the modified channeling characteristics.MATERIALS AND METHODSThe βA169L/βC170W mutant of TRPS was purified (9Ruvinov S.B. Yang X.J. Parris K.D. Banik U. Ahmed S.A. Miles E.W. Sackett D.L. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 6357-6369Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (57) Google Scholar, 16Miles E.W. Kawasaki H. Ahmed S.A. Morita H. Nagata S. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 6280-6287Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) and crystallized (11Schlichting I. Yang X.J. Miles E.W. Kim A.Y. Anderson K.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 26591-26593Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) as described previously. Diffraction data were collected of a crystal mounted in a capillary and kept at 4 °C at beam-line X12C at the National Synchrotron Light Source using a MAR Research image plate detector. The data were integrated and scaled with the HKL suite of programs (17Otwinowski Z. Minor W. Methods Enzymol. 1997; 276: 307-325Crossref Scopus (38361) Google Scholar). Refinement to 2.5 Å resolution was started with CNS 0.9a (18Brünger A.T. Adams P.D. Clore G.M. DeLano W.L. Gros P. Grosse-Kunstleve R.W. Jiang J.-S. Kuszewski J. Nilges M. Pannu N.S. Read R.J. Rice L.M. Simonson T. Warren G.L. Acta Crystallogr. Sect. D Biol. Crystallogr. 1998; 54: 905-921Crossref PubMed Scopus (16929) Google Scholar) by performing rigid body and simulated-annealing steps. The coordinates of the wild-type TRPSIPP complex (PDB code 1Q0P) were used as a starting model, omitting the coordinates of loops αL2 and αL6, IPP, the cofactor PLP, and all water molecules. The mutated residues were modeled as alanines to avoid model bias. The final model was built by cyclic rounds of manual model building with the program“O” (19Jones T.A. Zou J.Y. Cowan S.W. Kjelgaard M. Acta Crystallogr. Sect. A. 1991; 47: 110-119Crossref PubMed Scopus (13004) Google Scholar) and Maximum Likelihood refinement with the program REFMAC (20Murshudov G.N. Vagin A.A. Lebedev A. Wilson K.S. Dodson E.J. Acta Crystallogr. Sect. D Biol. Crystallogr. 1999; 55: 247-255Crossref PubMed Scopus (1005) Google Scholar) using all reflections from 20 to 2.25 Å. Water molecules were incorporated by ARP (21Lamzin V.S. Wilson K.S. Acta Crystallogr. Sect. D Biol. Crystallogr. 1993; 49: 129-147Crossref PubMed Google Scholar) using the automatic cut-off option. All waters were checked manually and removed if displaying unusual H-bonding geometry. Apart from residues at the C termini of both polypeptide chains, the only part of the βA169L/βC170WF-IPP complex that remains too disordered to be built into electron density is the C-terminal part of loop αL6 (αArg188-αPro192). As shown in Fig. 1 A, two regions in the β-subunit show disproportionately high B-factors (>2ς × <B> = 72 Å2, mean value <B> = 36 Å2): the first residues (βAla136-βSer143) of helix βH5 and the residues (βHis160-βAls164) preceding helix βH6 (secondary structure definition according to Ref. 12Schneider T.R. Gerhardt E. Lee M. Liang P.H. Anderson K.S. Schlichting I. Biochemistry. 1998; 37: 5394-5406Crossref PubMed Scopus (134) Google Scholar). Because both amino acid stretches belong to the COMM domain and may have structural and/or communicative functions, we retained these coordinates in the final model, although the final Sigma A-weighted 2 mFo − DFc (20Murshudov G.N. Vagin A.A. Lebedev A. Wilson K.S. Dodson E.J. Acta Crystallogr. Sect. D Biol. Crystallogr. 1999; 55: 247-255Crossref PubMed Scopus (1005) Google Scholar) and a composed-omit (18Brünger A.T. Adams P.D. Clore G.M. DeLano W.L. Gros P. Grosse-Kunstleve R.W. Jiang J.-S. Kuszewski J. Nilges M. Pannu N.S. Read R.J. Rice L.M. Simonson T. Warren G.L. Acta Crystallogr. Sect. D Biol. Crystallogr. 1998; 54: 905-921Crossref PubMed Scopus (16929) Google Scholar) maps show only very weak electron density. Open table in a new tab RESULTS AND DISCUSSIONThe structure of the double mutant βA169L/βC170W is of high quality as indicated by the low R-factors and the good stereochemistry (see Table II). The side chain conformations of the mutated amino acids are very well defined by the electron density (Fig. 2 A). The mutant has the same secondary and tertiary structure as the wild-type enzyme, and the overall topology is similar to the one assigned by Schneider et al. (12Schneider T.R. Gerhardt E. Lee M. Liang P.H. Anderson K.S. Schlichting I. Biochemistry. 1998; 37: 5394-5406Crossref PubMed Scopus (134) Google Scholar) that is observed in all TRPS structures. F-IPP binds (not shown) in a depression on the surface of the α-subunit and is held in place by several hydrogen bonds to the phosphate at the one end and hydrophobic interactions with the indole moiety at the other end, similar to the wild-type enzyme (12Schneider T.R. Gerhardt E. Lee M. Liang P.H. Anderson K.S. Schlichting I. Biochemistry. 1998; 37: 5394-5406Crossref PubMed Scopus (134) Google Scholar). Following, we compare the structures of the βA169L/βC170WF-IPP complex and the wild-type IPP complex (TRPSIPP, Protein Data Bank (PDB) code 1Q0P) (14Weyand M. Schlichting I. Biochemistry. 1999; 38: 16469-16480Crossref PubMed Scopus (76) Google Scholar). The reason is that the latter was determined to a much higher resolution than the TRPSF-IPP complex (PDB code 1A50) (12Schneider T.R. Gerhardt E. Lee M. Liang P.H. Anderson K.S. Schlichting I. Biochemistry. 1998; 37: 5394-5406Crossref PubMed Scopus (134) Google Scholar), and a comparison of both complexes shows high structural similarity; the superposition of 564 Cα pairs, excluding the COMM domain residues, gives a r.m.s. deviation of 0.36 Å for Cα atoms and 0.13 Å for the 17 common α-ligand atoms, respectively (Fig. 1 B). The low r.m.s. deviation value for the common α-ligand atoms indicates a high similarity of the α-ligand binding site and also for the enzyme, excluding the COMM domain; this shows that the additional fluorine atom in F-IPP compared with IPP has no influence on the TRPS structure. In particular, it does not change the COMM domain conformation (12Schneider T.R. Gerhardt E. Lee M. Liang P.H. Anderson K.S. Schlichting I. Miles E.W. Kim A.Y. Anderson K.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 26591-26593Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), the βTrp170 side chain points into the tunnel, thereby blocking it. In addition, because the bulky side chain of βC170W would clash with the βPhe280 side chain, the latter rotates by about 110° in χ1, and the backbone Φ/Ψ torsion angles change from Φ/ΨWT = 63.5°/23.2 to Φ/Ψmut = 55.4°/36.8°. The new side chain conformation of βPhe280 induces a χ1rotation of about 18° for βTyr279 (see Fig. 2); leading to a number of new interactions of its hydroxyl group. Of note is the hydrogen bond (2.6 Å) to the oxygen atom Oδ1 of asparagine βAsn171, which further forms a hydrogen bond (2.7 Å) to aspartate αAsp56Oδ2. This latter interaction is also found in wild-type TRPS structures (12Schneider T.R. Gerhardt E. Lee M. Liang P.H. Anderson K.S. Schlichting I. Biochemistry. 1998; 37: 5394-5406Crossref PubMed Scopus (134) Google Scholar, 14Weyand M. Schlichting I. Biochemistry. 1999; 38: 16469-16480Crossref PubMed Scopus (76) Google Scholar), but the interaction mediated by the asparagine βAsn171 between the side chain of a gating residue and a loop αLeu2 residue is seen only in the βA169L/βC170W mutant structure. In addition, the new conformation of the βTyr279 side chain results in an unfavorable contact between its hydroxyl group and the Cβ carbon atom of aspartate αAsp56 (2.7 Å). These interactions may influence the communication properties of the βA169L/βC170W mutant, because αAsp56 and βAsn171 are involved in the inter-subunit communication pathway (12Schneider T.R. Gerhardt E. Lee M. Liang P.H. Anderson K.S. Schlichting I. Biochemistry. 1998; 37: 5394-5406Crossref PubMed Scopus (134) Google Scholar).The main effect of the βC170W mutation on the gating residues βTyr279 and βPhe280 is a loss of rotational freedom. In particular, phenylalanine βPhe280 is trapped in a hydrophobic pocket built of side chains from αLeu58,βTrp170, βLeu174, βTyr279, βMet282, βMet286, βPhe306, and βPhe307. Although the conformations of βTyr279 and βPhe280correspond to an open gate in the βA169L/βC170WF-IPPcomplex, the tunnel is occluded by the indolyl side chain of βTrp170.Several COMM domain regions have significantly different conformations in the βA169L/βC170WF-IPP complex compared with the wild type (Figs. 1 B and 2 B). The changes are caused primarily by the introduction of leucine βLeu169, because its side chain would be too close to the adjacent amide nitrogen atom of βGly135 (distance 1.6 Å) and the Cα of βMet134 (distance 2.5 Å) located at the end of strand βS4. Their movement prevents this backbone clash and results in a domino effect-like rearrangement of the COMM domain; because strand βS4 is one of the middle β-strands of the four-stranded parallel COMM domain β-sheet and forms hydrogen bonds to residues of both neighboring strands βS3 and βS5, these strands and the N-terminal part of β-strand βS6 also move. The shift of all four COMM domain β-strands is conveyed by the movement of helix βH5 and loops βL3 and βL5. The maximum Cα atom shift of ∼3.5 Å is found at lysine βLys137. It is noteworthy that the catalytically important glutamate βGlu109 (4Anderson K.S. Miles E.W. Johnson K.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 21548-21557Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Although the side chain of aspartate βAsp305 points toward the β-active site (“swing in” position (13Rhee S. Parris K.D. Ahmed S.A. Miles E.W. Davies D.R. Biochemistry. 1996; 35: 4211-4221Crossref PubMed Scopus (137) Google Scholar)) in both the TRPSIPP (14Weyand M. Schlichting I. Biochemistry. 1999; 38: 16469-16480Crossref PubMed Scopus (76) Google Scholar) and the βA169L/βC170WF-IPPcomplex, there are significant differences. In the wild type, the distance between the carboxylate oxygen Oδ2of βAsp305 and the amide nitrogen of βGly111 is 3.4 Å, and the βAsp305carboxylate is linked via one or two water molecules to the COMM domain residues βAsp138, βGln142, and βThr165, respectively. This network is broken in the βA169L/βC170WF-IPP complex because the respective COMM domain residues are shifted from the core of the β-subunit due to the introduction of the leucine βLeu169 as described above (distance between Oδ2 of βAsp305 and the amide of βGly111 is 6.1 Å). This results in a loss of all water molecules involved in the hydrogen bonding network between βAsp305 and the COMM domain. Although we cannot exclude the possibility that the nonobservation of the bridging water molecules is due to the lower resolution of the diffraction data, careful analysis of the finalmFo − DFc electron density map at a very low cut-off shows no indication for bound water molecules in this region. In contrast, the final 2 mFo − DFc map shows clear backbone and side chain conformations for βAsp305 with Φ/Ψ torsion angles of −91.2°/16.5° compared with −90.8°/−6.2° in the TRPSIPP structure, indicating a small but significant conformational change because of the missing water contacts. Despite the changed conformation of βAsp305, the βA169L/βC170WF-IPP complex contains a sodium ion.
